References in Machine Learning and AI Research (2021-2024)
Andreas Krause, Emma Brunskill, Kyunghyun Cho, Barbara Engelhardt, Sivan Sabato, and Jonathan Scarlett edited Proceedings of the 40th International Conference on Machine Learning in July 2023.
Shuai Jia et al. published "Adv-attribute: Inconspicuous and transferable adversarial attack on face recognition" in Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems in 2022.
Shengming Yuan et al. published "Natural color fool: Towards boosting black-box unrestricted attacks" in Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems in 2022.
Jianqi Chen et al. published "Diffusion models for imperceptible and transferable adversarial attack" as an arXiv preprint in 2023.
Samuele Poppi et al. will publish "Safe-CLIP: Removing NSFW Concepts from Vision-and-Language Models" in the Proceedings of the European Conference on Computer Vision in 2024.
Han Bao et al. published "AutoBench-V: Can Large Vision-Language Models Benchmark Themselves?" as an arXiv preprint in 2024.
Felix Friedrich et al. published "Fair diffusion: Instructing text-to-image generation models on fairness" as an arXiv preprint in 2023.
Ziyi Kou et al. published "RAt: Injecting Implicit Bias for Text-To-Image Prompt Refinement Models" in the Proceedings of the 2024 Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing in November 2024.
Ninareh Mehrabi et al. published a survey on bias and fairness in machine learning in ACM computing surveys in 2021.
Virginia Dignum discussed the myth of complete AI-fairness in the 19th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Medicine in 2021.
Ajil Jalal et al. explored fairness for image generation with uncertain sensitive attributes in the International Conference on Machine Learning in 2021.
Jialu Wang et al. published "T2iat: Measuring valence and stereotypical biases in text-to-image generation" as an arXiv preprint in 2023.
Kathleen C Fraser and Svetlana Kiritchenko examined gender and racial bias in large vision-language models using a novel dataset of parallel images in an arXiv preprint in 2024.
Eddie L Ungless et al. studied stereotypes and representation of non-cisgender identities by text-to-image models in an arXiv preprint in 2023.
Abhipsa Basu et al. investigated the geographical representativeness of images from text-to-image models in the IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision in 2023.
Rida Qadri et al. conducted a community-centered study of text-to-image models in South Asia in the ACM Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency in 2023.
Lukas Struppek et al. explored exploiting cultural biases via homoglyphs in text-to-image synthesis.
